* Add `g_alignButtonAct` and make it visible when the editor is open

While rotate/translate/scale have issue #1329, align as implemented here doesn't.

values.description:
This pull request connects `SystemPaths` and `InsertModelWidget` in order to update the "Insert Models" tab upon changing GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH. 

`SystemPaths::AddModelPathsUpdate` calls `SystemPaths::AddModelPaths` to add the input path to the model path and then notifies `InsertModelWidget` via a `gazebo::Event`.

I am using these changes in my Building Editor branch, [building_editor_filesave](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/building_editor_filesave), to add finished models to the "Insert Models" tab. `SystemPaths::AddModelPathsUpdate` gets called in `gazebo/gui/building/BuildingMaker.cc`. Check it out if it is useful to your review.
values.title: Update InsertModelWidget using SystemPaths::AddModelPathsUpdate

values.description:
![filesave_schematic.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3904031974-filesave_schematic.png)

This pull request implements the file save behavior and GUI changes depicted in the above schematic (courtesy of Louise). It also provide a fix for issue 396: the building editor creates a folder with model.config and model.sdf files for a saved model, adds it to the model path, and notifies the InsertModelWidget to make the model is available in the "Insert Model" tab.

Disclaimer: There are a few known issues that I am leaving for future work:

~~1. On some computers, saving a model to the home folder causes Gazebo to crash. This happens if the hidden folder ~/.dbus is owned by root. If instructed to write to the home folder, the program will first attempt to write to .dbus, which will lead to a permission denied exception. This could be fixed by adding a try/catch block around the write, but this still does not allow the user to write models to the home folder. Suggestions for a complete fix are welcome.~~ independent of this pull request, will be solved in [PR 1329](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1329)

2. I believe the changes to FinishBuildingDialog should get merged into gui::SaveDialog and SaveDialog should be used in BuildingMaker. I am leaving this for a different pull request until after I have taken a closer look at SaveDialog.
values.title: Building Editor: Improved saving, pop-up flow, and palette buttons

summary.html:
This pull request implements the file save behavior and GUI changes depicted in the above schematic (courtesy of Louise). It also provide a fix for issue 396: the building editor creates a folder with model.config and model.sdf files for a saved model, adds it to the model path, and notifies the InsertModelWidget to make the model is available in the "Insert Model" tab.

Disclaimer: There are a few known issues that I am leaving for future work:

1. On some computers, saving a model to the home folder causes Gazebo to crash. This happens if the hidden folder ~/.dbus is owned by root. If instructed to write to the home folder, the program will first attempt to write to .dbus, which will lead to a permission denied exception. This could be fixed by adding a try/catch block around the write, but this still does not allow the user to write models to the home folder. Suggestions for a complete fix are welcome. independent of this pull request, will be solved in PR 1329

  1. I believe the changes to FinishBuildingDialog should get merged into gui::SaveDialog and SaveDialog should be used in BuildingMaker. I am leaving this for a different pull request until after I have taken a closer look at SaveDialog.

This is something similar to what @scpeters did in his branch [sdformat_protobuf](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/sdformat_protobuf..gazebo_3.1#chg-gazebo/msgs/msgs_TEST.cc) branch. Model editor currently needs this functionality so I added the necessary functions to make the model editor work for now. 

Note that a better way to do the conversion is proposed in this [gazebo design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/10/add-design-doc-for-converting-protobuf/diff). Once that's implemented, I can switch the model editor to use the new method for sdf conversion.

values.description:
This enables Coulomb joint friction for BulletHingeJoint, which is part of #1348 (the rest would be BulletSliderJoint and BulletUniversalJoint).

I'll describe this pull request based on its 4 commits:

 c16db73: enable joint friction test for bullet, which fails

7d84070: Implement Coulomb joint friction for BulletHingeJoint. The creates overloaded `BulletHingeJoint::[GS]etParam` functions, which are needed since the API for setting friction is different for each bullet joint. Bullet actually takes an impulse instead of a torque, so it is required to scale the friction according to the time step size.

316528c: Add `[GS]etParam` functions for BulletSliderJoint and BulletUniversal joint now while ABI is changeable. I also tried to implement friction for the slider joint, but it's not yet working.

63a1389: Add `Joint::GetJointType`, which can be used with `msgs::ConvertJointType` to get a string representation of the joint type. I added this because it was not straightforward to get the joint type as a string any other way. The function is tested and used in a console message in `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn`.
values.title: Enable joint friction for BulletHingeJoint (part of #1348)

values.description:
Louise discovered a bug where calling `Visual::SetMaterial` on a Visual made that item opaque, even when Visual::transparency was less than 1. I've noticed that uses of SetMaterial for a transparent object throughout Gazebo (see `rendering::AxisVisual`, `rendering::OrbitViewController`) use a transparent material, which may be why this bug was not noticed before.

This pull request changes `Visual::SetMaterial` to use the last transparency value set for the Visual to apply the same transparency filter to the model after the material has been applied. For some reason, calling `Visual::SetMaterial` then `Visual::SetTransparency` did not set the transparency of the desired object. Someone who has used Ogre more than I have can explain this to me.

You can see this bug by setting the texture of the floor in branch [hitl_textures_inspector_transp](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/hitl_textures_inspector_transp), and compare the fix in [hitl_textures_inspector_transp_jackie](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/hitl_textures_inspector_transp_jackie), which is a superset of the changes in this PR.
values.title: Set transparency in `Visual::SetMaterial`

summary.raw:
Louise discovered a bug where calling `Visual::SetMaterial` on a Visual made that item opaque, even when Visual::transparency was less than 1. I've noticed that uses of SetMaterial for a transparent object throughout Gazebo (see `rendering::AxisVisual`, `rendering::OrbitViewController`) use a transparent material, which may be why this bug was not noticed before.

This pull request changes `Visual::SetMaterial` to use the last transparency value set for the Visual to apply the same transparency filter to the model after the material has been applied. For some reason, calling `Visual::SetMaterial` then `Visual::SetTransparency` did not set the transparency of the desired object. Someone who has used Ogre more than I have can explain this to me.

You can see this bug by setting the texture of the floor in branch [hitl_textures_inspector_transp](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/hitl_textures_inspector_transp), and compare the fix in [hitl_textures_inspector_transp_jackie](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/hitl_textures_inspector_transp_jackie), which is a superset of the changes in this PR.
summary.html:
Louise discovered a bug where calling Visual::SetMaterial on a Visual made that item opaque, even when Visual::transparency was less than 1. I've noticed that uses of SetMaterial for a transparent object throughout Gazebo (see rendering::AxisVisual, rendering::OrbitViewController) use a transparent material, which may be why this bug was not noticed before.

This pull request changes Visual::SetMaterial to use the last transparency value set for the Visual to apply the same transparency filter to the model after the material has been applied. For some reason, calling Visual::SetMaterial then Visual::SetTransparency did not set the transparency of the desired object. Someone who has used Ogre more than I have can explain this to me.

You can see this bug by setting the texture of the floor in branch hitl_textures_inspector_transp, and compare the fix in hitl_textures_inspector_transp_jackie, which is a superset of the changes in this PR.

values.description:
This PR accomplishes:

1. Position, camera, and laser interface compatibility with Player.

1. Removes old player .cfg files to eliminate confusion.

1. Adds three new worlds:

    1. Pioneer2dx + camera

    1. Pioneer2dx  + laser

    1. Pioneer2dx  + laser + camera

Here are the [tutorials](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/121).

To test, you'll need to install Player from source. [Here](https://www.dropbox.com/s/0b6lzjk9e0ewulb/player.tar.gz?dl=0) a version of player that compiles on trusty using the following cmake command:


```
#!cmake

cmake -DBUILD_EXAMPLES=OFF -DPLAYER_BUILD_TESTS=OFF -DENABLE_DRIVER_READLOG=OFF -DBUILD_CC_TESTS=OFF ..
```
values.title: Update to player interfaces

summary.raw:
This PR accomplishes:

1. Position, camera, and laser interface compatibility with Player.

1. Removes old player .cfg files to eliminate confusion.

1. Adds three new worlds:

    1. Pioneer2dx + camera

    1. Pioneer2dx  + laser

    1. Pioneer2dx  + laser + camera

Here are the [tutorials](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/121).

To test, you'll need to install Player from source. [Here](https://www.dropbox.com/s/0b6lzjk9e0ewulb/player.tar.gz?dl=0) a version of player that compiles on trusty using the following cmake command:


```
#!cmake

cmake -DBUILD_EXAMPLES=OFF -DPLAYER_BUILD_TESTS=OFF -DENABLE_DRIVER_READLOG=OFF -DBUILD_CC_TESTS=OFF ..
```
summary.html:
This PR accomplishes:

  1. Position, camera, and laser interface compatibility with Player.

  2. Removes old player .cfg files to eliminate confusion.

  3. Adds three new worlds:

    1. Pioneer2dx + camera

    2. Pioneer2dx + laser

    3. Pioneer2dx + laser + camera

Here are the tutorials.

To test, you'll need to install Player from source. Here a version of player that compiles on trusty using the following cmake command:

cmake -DBUILD_EXAMPLES=OFF -DPLAYER_BUILD_TESTS=OFF -DENABLE_DRIVER_READLOG=OFF -DBUILD_CC_TESTS=OFF ..

values.description: `common::KeyEvent` has no way of communicating to the user whether Control, Alt or Shift was helding during a keypress. This pull request adds this functionality.
values.title: Fixed documentation, added key modifiers to KeyEvent

summary.raw: `common::KeyEvent` has no way of communicating to the user whether Control, Alt or Shift was helding during a keypress. This pull request adds this functionality.
summary.html: common::KeyEvent has no way of communicating to the user whether Control, Alt or Shift was helding during a keypress. This pull request adds this functionality.

values.description:
This PR fixes the player position2d interface to use the correct message type when subscribing to pose updates.  It also fixes some warnings from libgazebo_player trying to link against itself, and corrects an error in the position2d interface where the z position was being filled in to the yaw field.

If there's an easy way to get the x, y, and angular velocities of the model, I can update the PR to fill in the velocity fields of the player position2d data message as well.  I did a cursory search but couldn't figure out which topics I need to subscribe to.

values.description:
QT's `findChild` function would return NULL when trying to find an object of type `QtTreePropertyBrowser`. My theory is that `QtTreePropertyBrowser` is not part of Qt core, which causes a problem.

This PR modifies the test to get a `QObject` first, then cast to `QtTreePropertyBrowser`.
values.title: Fix model list widget test

summary.raw:
QT's `findChild` function would return NULL when trying to find an object of type `QtTreePropertyBrowser`. My theory is that `QtTreePropertyBrowser` is not part of Qt core, which causes a problem.

This PR modifies the test to get a `QObject` first, then cast to `QtTreePropertyBrowser`.
summary.html:
QT's findChild function would return NULL when trying to find an object of type QtTreePropertyBrowser. My theory is that QtTreePropertyBrowser is not part of Qt core, which causes a problem.

This PR modifies the test to get a QObject first, then cast to QtTreePropertyBrowser.

values.description:
Here's a fun bug:

Open up Gazebo on default branch. Point your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` environment variable to a folder that is readable only by root, or `chmod` something that's already on your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` so that it's only readable by `root`. Then start Gazebo. It will crash with a message like:
```
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::filesystem::filesystem_error'
  what():  boost::filesystem::status: Permission denied: "/home/jackie/gazebo_models/foo/model.config"
```

I discovered this bug working on the building editor. Some users had folders in their home folder that were owned by root (even worse, a hidden folder, .dbus). The home folder seems like a reasonable default location to leave models, but the problem arose when I tried to add the home folder to the paths displayed in `InsertModelWidget` (the Qt widget that shows the "Insert Model" tab).

This pull request catches the issue by first checking if the user has permission to access a directory before attempting to read it into the Insert Model tab.
values.title: Bugfix for permission denied crash

~~Branches off of [PR 1325](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1325/fixed-documentation-added-key-modifiers-to/diff), but I wanted to get this out the door before the end of our DRCSim sprint week.~~

Implemented copy/past functionality in `ModelCreator`. The Model Editor now uses `g_pasteAct` and `g_copyAct` to get copy/paste events. I also added a boolean to GLWidget to check when the model editor is running so that GLWidget's copy/paste function won't collide with the Model Editor's, since the shortcuts are the same.

values.description:
Issue #1299 was initially fixed by pull request #1232, but there was an error in that fix. Specifically, there was an error in the regular expression used to parse the `gzserver` process id (pid) from the `ps` command output. Here's an example of `ps` command output with pid of 12345:
~~~
12345 ?        Sl     4:56 gzserver /tmp/clone.11347.world
~~~

This mistake was that the regular expression didn't allow for whitespace at the beginning of the line, but this can happen if a process id has a smaller number of digits than the system maximum. For example, the following was logged from my computer that has initial whitespace and [shows a python error in the log file](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/a355665271490e81c381):
~~~
 9980 ?        Sl     1:23 gzserver /tmp/clone.11347.world
~~~
This pull request fixes the regular expression and adds some logic to verify that the `re.search` command was successful.

I ran a [jenkins test](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/116/) of branch issue_1299_failtest, which was patched in a28957b642c to force failures of the `INTEGRATION_world_clone` test that leaves `gzserver`'s behind. It sucessfully killed the rogue process.
values.title: Prevent rogue gzserver's after failed INTEGRATION_world_clone tests, update (#1299)

The `REGRESSION_config-cmake` has been [failing in jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/153/testReport/junit/%28root%29/Cmake/Config/) for a couple of weeks with the following error:
~~~
321: CMake Error at CMakeLists.txt:9 (find_package):
321:   Could not find a configuration file for package "gazebo" that is compatible
321:   with requested version "4.100000".
321: 
321:   The following configuration files were considered but not accepted:
321: 
321:     /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/gazebo/gazebo-config.cmake, version: 4.1.0
~~~
Somehow the minor version is going from 1 to 100000. The fix is to treat it as a string rather than floating point number.

I have verified the fix on my local machine and will post jenkins results when they are available.

UPDATE:

* test is [fixed in jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/369/testReport/(root)/Cmake/)

values.description:
This pull request enables the C++11 support. There is an issue with GTEST when using `EXPECT`, `ASSERT`, `QVERIFY`, and we pass a shared pointer as an argument. The boost::shared_ptr bool operator is explicit and the compiler does not make an implicit conversion for us when we're using these GTEST macros.

I would say that the cleanest solution would be to use the bool operator in the form of a static_cast<bool>(mysharedPtr) or bool(mysharedPtr). However we have lots of lines where we are comparing the shared pointer with NULL. So, for consistency this is the way I chose here to fix the problem.

There are other ways as redeclaring ASSERT_TRUE with a different name and wrap it with a new ASSERT_TRUE but I don't think it's worth it.

For reference, there was some discussion in pull request #1297.
values.title: C++11 support (take 2)

values.description:
Issue #1354 is related to an ABI conflict in gazebo4 that would occur when merging the gazebo_2.2 branch forward (caused by a combination of pull request #1284 and pull request #1183, see #1354 for more details).

This pull request fixes the ABI conflict by deleting the new variables `ODELink::force` and `ODELink::torque` and instead using `Link::linearAccel` and `Link::angularAccel`, which are pre-existing, unused variables. It's a little dirty by should be fine.

[ABI report shows that it is fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-precise-amd64/131/API_ABI_report/)
